ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to speak Japanese on formal and casual levels, thinking more in Japanese and using words we already know to describe something we don't know the exact vocabulary for, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: weakness: did not get feedback from assignments, homework assignments would be assigned without warning in the afternoon

Strengths: Builds on your toolbox of Japanese vocabulary and grammar, emphasis on Japanese culture in addition to the language, the teacher tried making it fun with things like occasional music videos, Totoro, etc.

Weakness: Feedback was pretty delayed (if any) and sometimes not clear

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: to finish L3, but expect to put in work
If you're interested in Japanese, then of course, however, note that the difficulty is greater than what is experienced in the first two courses
